After one play-through of this game I can confidently say the feelings I had while playing this game were mainly discomfort, tension and claustrophobia. In addition to this games discomfort it is also extremely engaging, both in game-play and story. This was a huge amount of fun to play and genuinely difficult. This game requires you to actively solve puzzles to get from A to B rather than just simply surviving which were sometimes far more tricky than I was expecting. If you haven't played this game, I recommend you do

This game is an absolute legend. Who hasn't played this, must do this at least once in their life.
What to say here? Half-Life is a title known to nearly everyone, from the oldest to the youngest ones.
It is a game which brought huge success and created a new generation of games.
Even graphics, although the game was released in 1998, is still beautiful.
You can feel a lot of work that Valve did. Models, especially of weapons, are masterpiece.
They have many visible details that please the eye and make that the weapons are nothing worse than those from current games.
[spoiler]An animation in which Gordon tries to pet an alien in one weapon is perfect[/spoiler]
Music is also epic. It is very climatic and fits ideally at every moment in the plot.
And the plot itself. What to say? That plot created a great and popular brand that stayed in hearts of many, many players. Till now, almost 2 decades from releasing Half-Life 2, players still wait for Half-Life 3 :)
Thus, if you wonder whether you should play this game after all those years, DO IT without thinking!
Very nice game, stands the test of time I'd say. Next is Opposing force.

I know this game is very popular, but it's a 1998 game and... well, it definitely feels like one. I'm happy enough about having tried this but I don't think I can recommend it to anyone who isn't specifically into old games. 

I guess I'll check if the fanmade remake Black Mesa can blow some new life into this game, but I sadly don't think I could stomach playing this one to the end.
For both its flaws and strengths, it is beyond being a simple game, it is an experience.

Throughout my child-hood, I've always played CS 1.6. I knew about Half-life, but I never really decided to play it for myself until recently. And suffice to say; I really enjoyed this game. Now personally, I think because I'm one of the very few people on this planet that got to play HL blind, I honestly think that furthered my positive reception towards the game.

10/10 - No matter what kind of games you like, this is a must get for anyone's Steam library.

is ok

Half-Life is a terrific game; very, very few things to complain about (the godd*mn fall damage on Hard difficulty is one of them).  

The game I contrast Half-Life with most is Deus Ex; both are from the same era; both have slow/semi-realistic shooting (contrasted to Quake games, etc.); both have huge maps and are quite long; both were hailed as pretty much consensus Games of their respective Years.  While I like Deus Ex more (for the ability to complete missions in a variety of ways and via different routes, plus the characters and music [Half-Life's soundtrack is fine, but Deus Ex is a level above]), I have to admit that Half-Life doesn't have as many flaws nor as much clunkiness as Deus Ex; it's definitely a smoother experience.  

I've read online that making the protagonist silent is some sort of genius act of storytelling, yadda, yadda.  I consider this akin to a player being on multiple Super Bowl-winning teams being the best at his position (Tom Brady is the ultimate example of this; people just casually call him the greatest because of his rings, ignoring the facts that 1) the title of greatest is an individual honor, 2) winning Super Bowls are team accomplishments, and 3) other players have better individual resumes).  It's not a bad character choice, mind, just a bit odd that this MIT grad never says anything to his colleagues as the world collapses around him.  I chose to interpret Freeman's character to be a serial killer who went to MIT to establish a cover for his deranged habit; now that everything is coming apart, he's taking out his anger on everyone else.  Basically, I read him as being a bit crazy.  I find this far more interesting, especially in the second game, in which Freeman is regarded in almost Messianic terms.  

The game is solid; it does what it sets out to do.  Check it out.

I'm a former fan of Blizzard Entertainment and current Blizzard Entertainment (garbage) has to learn a LOT from Crowbar Collective. Here is some comparison disregarding the genre. Crowbar Collective spent whopping 13+ years on re-making this game (BLACK MESA) and the outcome was, obviously overwhelmingly positive opinion'd game. Warcraft 3 Reforged was supposed to be a REMAKE (not just remaster) just like FF7 but they spent almost little to no time and later whined (lied basically) to people that they have to spend 1-2 more weeks to ensure a so called themselves a 'Blizzard Quality' (total bullshit) and released it on 2020. Outcome was obviously guinness world record for worst game in entire human history. It was basically downgraded game even compared to the original that came out on 2003 (GOTY, 92% metacritic). Now they're talking about Overwatch 2 which is basically Overwatch + Single player mission based and probably more video graphics requirement (are you f**king serious). I'm just trying to say that AAA companies are nothing now, they have to learn from individuals how to make a proper game instead of developing massive numbers of in-game purchase for their own sake. I don't know nor care what his name is but the current owner of the Blizzard (that quaker looking long haired motherf**ker) needs to see this and learn from his mistakes.

I've always stood by this game and they just keep breaking records and improving on the last game. This is an incredible game that really changes your perspective on science and how it is used.
